questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about NREM sleep?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

Dreaming does occur during NREM sleep, but it is typically lucid and purposeful, unlike REM dreams, which are abstract and surreal.

Explanation of other options:

Nightmares are commonly associated with NREM sleep (Option D): Incorrect – Nightmares occur during REM sleep. Sleep terrors, not nightmares, are associated with NREM sleep (especially stage N3).

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Section A in the sleep cycle hypnogram shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

The figure referenced in the question is a hypnogram, which is a graphical representation of the stages of sleep across the night. It plots time on the x-axis (typically in hours) and sleep depth or stage on the y-axis.

  • Section A represents REM latency — the time from sleep onset (not wakefulness) to the first REM phase.
  • NREM sleep typically begins shortly after sleep onset, not at the end of Section A.

The hypnogram shows:

  1. Sleep Cycles Across the Night:
    • A person cycles through NREM and REM sleep about 4 to 6 times per night.
    • Each full cycle lasts approximately 90–120 minutes.
    • The graph dips into deeper NREM stages and then ascends into REM, repeatedly.
  2. NREM Sleep:
    • Made up of four stages (N1, N2, N3, and N4) — although N3 and N4 are often combined as "slow-wave sleep" or deep sleep.
    • In the hypnogram, deeper stages (like N3) are shown as lower dips.
    • The first few cycles have more deep sleep (N3).
  3. REM Sleep:
    • Shown as sharp upward spikes or plateaus following each cycle of NREM sleep.
    • REM periods are shorter earlier in the night and get longer later in the night.
  4. REM Latency (Section A):
    • This is the part labeled as “Section A” in the question.
    • It shows the time from falling asleep (sleep onset) to the first REM episode. (Option A ruled out)
    • Normally lasts about 90–120 minutes in healthy adults. (Option C ruled out)
    • Shortened in conditions like:
      • Depression
      • Narcolepsy
      • Withdrawal from alcohol, barbiturates, TCAs, MAOIs, amphetamines (Option D ruled out)
  5. Sleep Architecture Changes Through the Night:
    • As night progresses:
      • Less slow-wave sleep
      • More REM sleep
      • Sleep becomes lighter

questions.text: Which waves are predominantly seen during the wakeful state with eyes closed?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

When a person is awake but relaxed with their eyes closed, the dominant EEG rhythm is:

  • Alpha waves
    • Frequency: 8–13 Hz
    • Location: Most prominent in the posterior head regions (occipital lobes)
    • Seen in: Calm, wakeful state with eyes closed (but alert and not drowsy)
    • Disappears when eyes are opened or during mental effort (this is called alpha blocking)

questions.text: A 32-year-old software engineer complains of difficulty falling asleep and frequent awakenings at night for the past 3 months. He reports working late into the night, drinking green tea in the evening to "relax," and watching calming videos in bed. As part of sleep hygiene education, which of the following behaviors is least consistent with good sleep practices?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

While green tea is often considered healthy and calming, it contains caffeine, a central nervous system stimulant that can interfere with the ability to fall asleep. Even "decaffeinated" green tea can contain small amounts of caffeine, and some people are particularly sensitive to it.

  • In sleep hygiene, avoiding any stimulants like coffee, cola, energy drinks, or green/black tea in the evening is strongly recommended.
  • Caffeine can delay the onset of sleep, reduce total sleep time, and affect sleep quality.

Dos for Good Sleep Hygiene

  • Maintain regular hours of bedtime and arising
  • Have a light snack before bedtime if you're hungry
  • Maintain a regular exercise schedule (but not right before bed)
  • Give yourself about an hour to wind down before going to bed
  • If you're worried about something at bedtime, write it down and deal with it in the morning
  • Keep the bedroom cool, dark, and quiet

Don’ts for Good Sleep Hygiene

  • Don’t take naps during the day
  • Don’t watch the clock to see how bad your insomnia is
  • Don’t exercise right before going to bed
  • Don’t watch television in bed when you cannot sleep
  • Don’t eat a heavy meal before bedtime
  • Don’t drink coffee in the afternoon or evening
  • Don’t smoke a cigarette if you cannot sleep
  • Don’t use alcohol to help in going to sleep
  • Don’t read in bed when you cannot sleep
  • Don’t eat in bed
  • Don’t exercise in bed
  • Don’t talk on the phone in bed

Explanation of Other Options:

Using the bed only for sleep and intimacy (Option A): This is a core principle of sleep hygiene. The idea is to train the brain to associate the bed with only sleep and sex. Doing other activities like watching TV, working, or scrolling on the phone in bed weakens this association, making it harder to fall asleep.

Having a light snack like warm milk before bed (Option B): Light, healthy snacks (such as warm milk or a banana) can sometimes help with sleep. Milk contains tryptophan, an amino acid that helps promote the production of serotonin and melatonin, neurochemicals involved in sleep regulation.

Avoiding naps in the late afternoon (Option D): Late afternoon or evening naps reduce sleep pressure and can make it harder to fall asleep at night. Short naps (≤30 minutes) earlier in the day may be refreshing, but longer naps or naps taken too late can disrupt the natural circadian rhythm.

questions.text: Klein-Levin syndrome is characterised by all of the following features except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

Profound insomnia is not a feature of KLS. Hypersomnia (not insomnia) is the hallmark.

Kleine–Levin Syndrome (KLS) is a rare but well-recognized recurrent hypersomnia disorder primarily affecting adolescent males, although females and older individuals can also be affected.

Key Clinical Features of KLS:

  • Recurrent episodes of hypersomnolence, where individuals sleep up to 18–20 hours per day. (Option A ruled out)
  • These episodes last for days to weeks, occurring intermittently with normal functioning between episodes.
  • During the wakeful periods within an episode, patients often:
    • Withdraw socially
    • Return to bed quickly
    • Exhibit disinhibited behaviors such as hyperphagia (excessive eating), hypersexuality, and aggression. (Option C and D ruled out)
  • Onset is typically during adolescence (between 10–21 years), but rare cases are reported even in the 40s or 50s.
  • Episodes may occur once to 10 times per year.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presented with complaints of non-refreshing sleep and an irresistible urge to fall asleep during the day despite 8-9 hours of night sleep. These sleep attacks would even occur at inappropriate times, like during work or even while having a conversation. He frequently has frightening hallucinations while falling asleep at night, and also frequently experiences body paralysis in which he awakens unable to move even his eyelids for a few seconds. Which of the following is/are true regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

The case describes narcolepsy, a chronic sleep disorder characterized by dysregulation of REM sleep, resulting in REM intruding into wakefulness. (Option A)

Characteristic Features (Narcoleptic Tetrad):

  1. Excessive Daytime Sleepiness (EDS)
    • Most consistent and often earliest symptom
    • The patient may fall asleep mid-conversation or while eating
  2. Cataplexy (seen in Type 1):
    • Sudden loss of muscle tone triggered by strong emotions (e.g., laughter, anger)
    • Consciousness preserved
  3. Hypnagogic or Hypnopompic Hallucinations
    • Vivid, often frightening visual or auditory experiences at sleep onset or awakening
  4. Sleep Paralysis
    • Temporary inability to move or speak despite being conscious, typically at awakening

Pathophysiology:

  • Hypocretin (orexin) deficiency in the cerebrospinal fluid (especially in Type 1 narcolepsy) (Option B)
  • Shortened REM latency (REM begins within 15 minutes of sleep onset)

Diagnostic Criteria (DSM-5):

  • Symptoms ≥3 times/week for ≥3 months
  • At least one of the following:
    • Cataplexy
    • CSF hypocretin deficiency
    • Sleep onset REM within 15 minutes on PSG or MSLT

Types of Narcolepsy:

  • Type 1: With cataplexy and/or hypocretin deficiency
  • Type 2: Without cataplexy, normal hypocretin

Treatment:

  • Modafinil:
    • First-line treatment to reduce daytime sleepiness (Option C)
    • FDA approved
  • Other agents:
    • Sodium oxybate (helps with cataplexy and sleep consolidation)
    • Stimulants (e.g., amphetamines)
    • SSRIs/SNRIs for REM-related symptoms (e.g., hallucinations, cataplexy)

choices.text: Somnambulism
Sleep terrors
REM sleep behaviour disorder
Periodic limb movement disorder

questions.text: A 30-year-old male student presented with a 7-year history of abnormal sleep in the form of punching and kicking, often accompanied by screaming in insulting language, lasting for several seconds. The patient would often be woken up by his wife during these episodes, and on waking up, he reported the content of his dreams in which he would either be participating in a robbery or was being attacked by an animal or running away from someone. In one episode, he had even hit the wall and broken his wrist. Overnight polysomnography showed a lack of normal muscle paralysis during REM sleep. Which of the following diagnoses is appropriate for his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD) is a parasomnia characterized by:

  • Loss of normal muscle atonia (paralysis) during REM sleep
  • Leads to physically acting out vivid, intense, or violent dreams, such as punching, kicking, or shouting
  • May result in injury to the patient or their bed partner
  • The dream content is often vividly recalled upon awakening and typically involves threatening or aggressive scenarios

Pathophysiology:

  • Normally, REM sleep is accompanied by skeletal muscle paralysis (to prevent dream enactment)
  • In RBD, this mechanism fails, allowing motor behaviors to emerge from REM dream content
  • This disorder may precede neurodegenerative diseases like Parkinson's disease, Lewy body dementia, or Multiple System Atrophy (RBD is often the earliest sign)

Diagnostic Criteria (DSM-5):

  • Repeated arousal during sleep
  • Vocalization or complex motor behavior
  • Occurs during REM sleep
  • Not confused when awakened
  • Either:
    • REM sleep without atonia on polysomnography
    • OR history consistent with REM sleep behaviors with established diagnosis of a synucleinopathy (i.e., Parkinson's disease)

Explanation of other options:

Somnambulism (Sleepwalking) (Option A): Occurs during NREM sleep (stage 3). Involves automatic, non-aggressive behaviors. No dream recall, and not associated with injury as commonly

Sleep Terrors (Option B): Also NREM-related. Sudden arousal with screaming and panic, no detailed dream recall. Occurs mostly in children

Periodic Limb Movement Disorder (PLMD) (Option D): Characterized by stereotyped, rhythmic leg movements. Occurs without dream enactment or violent behavior. Not associated with vivid dream content or violent injury

choices.text: Night terrors
Nightmares
Hypnagogic hallucinations
Both A and B

questions.text: After experiencing a road traffic accident in which she lost her brother, an 11-year-old girl presented with difficulty in sleep due to terrifying dreams involving the accident, which are prolonged and awaken her. On waking up, she remembers the dreams and finds herself sweating, panting, and her heart racing. Due to such frequent fearful dreams, she often has a fear of sleeping. Which of the following would best describe her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

Nightmare Disorder, as per DSM-5, is characterized by:

  • Disturbing, vivid dreams that typically occur during REM sleep
  • The content is threatening, anxiety-provoking, and often involves life-threatening events (e.g., trauma)
  • On awakening:
    • The individual is fully alert and oriented
    • Can recall the dream vividly
    • Exhibits autonomic symptoms: increased heart rate, sweating, rapid breathing
  • Frequently associated with Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)
  • Often leads to insomnia or fear of sleep (somniphobia) due to anticipation of recurrence
  • Common in children aged 3–6 years, but can also persist or present later, especially after trauma
  • Triggers may include:
    • PTSD
    • Withdrawal from REM-suppressing medications (e.g., alcohol, antidepressants)
    • Use of drugs like L-DOPA, β-blockers

questions.text: A 36-year-old female, who was taking treatment for depression since last year, presented with complaints of pain and discomfort in her legs while lying down at night. She would rub and thrash her legs, tie pieces of clothes around her legs, ask for limb massage, or walk around a bit to get relief from the discomfort. Which is true regarding her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

The patient reports an urge to move the legs, worsening at night, and temporary relief with movement, matching criteria for Restless Leg Syndrome (RLS). Her behavior (rubbing, thrashing, walking, and massage) further supports circadian discomfort relieved by activity, a hallmark of RLS.

RLS is a sensorimotor neurological disorder involving:

  • An urge to move the legs,
  • Usually accompanied by uncomfortable sensations (creepy-crawly, itching, burning),
  • Occurring during rest or inactivity (especially at night),
  • Partially or completely relieved by movement,
  • Showing a circadian pattern (worse in the evening/night).

Epidemiology:

  • More common in middle-aged and older adults, and females.
  • May be idiopathic or secondary to medical conditions.

Common Causes:

  • Iron deficiency anemia (especially ↓ferritin levels)
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • Pregnancy
  • Neuropathy
  • Medications (especially:
    • Mirtazapine, an antidepressant that increases serotonin and can worsen RLS.
    • SSRIs, antipsychotics, and dopamine-blocking agents.)

DSM-5 Criteria Highlights:

  • Occurs ≥3 times/week for ≥3 months.
  • Must not be explained by another condition (e.g., akathisia, drug effects).
  • Causes significant distress or impairment in functioning.

Treatment:

  • Address underlying causes: Check serum ferritin, supplement if low.
  • First-line pharmacological treatment:
    • Dopaminergic agonists (e.g., pramipexole, ropinirole),
    • Gabapentin/pregabalin in cases with pain or insomnia.
  • Avoid triggering meds (e.g., mirtazapine).

Explanation of Other Options:

Serum ferritin should be checked (Option A): Iron deficiency is a well-established reversible cause of RLS. Even if hemoglobin is normal, ferritin <50 ng/mL can contribute to symptoms.

Mirtazapine can induce such a condition (Option B): Correct. Mirtazapine is associated with increased serotonergic tone, which can exacerbate or trigger RLS.

Dopaminergic antagonists have a promising role (Option C): Incorrect. Dopamine antagonists worsen RLS and may precipitate symptoms. Dopamine agonists, on the other hand, are part of first-line therapy.
